div.l: Vpon the floor / and there a swoıı̄un he lay
Vp stirte hir alisoıı̄un and Nicolay
And cried out and harrow in the strete
The neighebores boþe smale and grete
In ronne for to gauren on this man
That a swoıı̄un lay bothe pale and wan
For wᵗith þat fal he brosten hadde his arm
But stonden he muste vnto his owne harm
For whan he spak he was anon bore doıı̄un
With hende Nicolas and alisoıı̄un
They tolde eủery man þat he was wood
He was a gast so of Noes flood
Thurgh fantasie þat of his vanite
He hadde y bought hym knedyng tubbes thre
And hadde hem hanged in þe roof a boue
And þᵗat he praied hem for goddes loue
To sitte in þe roof ꝑpar companie
The folk gan laughen at his fantasie
And to þe roof they kyken and þey gape
And torned al his harm vnto a iape
For what so þis carpent̉er answerde
It was for nought no man his resoıı̄un herde
With oþes grete he was so born a doıı̄un
That he was halden wood in al þe toıı̄un
For eủery clerk anon right heeld with oþer
The said þe man is wood my leue brother
And eủery wight gan laughen at þis stryf
Thus swyued was þe Carpents wyf
For al his kepyng / and his Ialousye
And absolon hath kist hir nether eye
And Nicolas is scalded in his toute
This tale is doon ⁊and god saue al þis route
Thus endeth the Millers tale

and begynneth
the Prologe of the Reue
Whan folk han laughen at this nyce caas
Of Absolon and heende Nicolas
Diủerse folk diủersely the seide
But for þe part þe lowh ⁊and pleide
Ne at þis tale I saugh no man hym greue
